review.title: SMPOST: Parts of Speech Tagger for Code-Mixed Indic Social Media Text
review.abstract: Use of social media has grown dramatically during the last few years. Users follow informal languages in communicating through social media. The language of communication is often mixed in nature, where people transcribe their regional language with English and this technique is found to be extremely popular. Natural language processing (NLP) aims to infer the information from these text where Part-of-Speech (PoS) tagging plays an important role in getting the prosody of the written text. For the task of PoS tagging on Code-Mixed Indian Social Media Text, we develop a supervised system based on Conditional Random Field classifier. In order to tackle the problem effectively, we have focused on extracting rich linguistic features. We participate in three different language pairs, ie. English-Hindi, English-Bengali and English-Telugu on three different social media platforms, Twitter, Facebook & WhatsApp. The proposed system is able to successfully assign coarse as well as fine-grained PoS tag labels for a given a code-mixed sentence. Experiments show that our system is quite generic that shows encouraging performance levels on all the three language pairs in all the domains.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The sheer access to the Internet has led to increased mass participation in social media. In the last decade, the content of the Indian language on various media types such as blogs, emails, websites and chats has increased significantly. With the advent of smartphones, more people have access to social media through WhatsApp, Twitter, Facebook, through which they share their opinions on people, products, organizations and governments. The wealth of social media data has created many new ways of accessing information, but has also led to many novel challenges. Part-of-Speech (PoS) tagging is a fundamental task of Natural Language Processing. Many overarching NLP tasks require input as a posttagged sentence for parsing. The result of PoS tagging to English-Spanish code-mixed data has been in (Solorio and Liu, 2008) English.

sections.heading: 2 Rule based PoS Tagging
sections.text: The task of developing systems for predicting PoS is therefore immensely complex. Before sending word tokens for classification, it is necessary to remove the inappropriate tokens, including all residuals, digits, emoticons, website links, and twitter-specific word tokens such as "@," #, ~, "and many more. To address the variations of such tokens in the test data, we are developing a rules-based system for sequential removal of one type after another. We started by removing all punctuations and their respective extensions such as...,". "and" ~. "Next, we tackled all numerical tokens, including tokens that begin with a numerical entry and end with" st, "" nd, "" rd, "" th "for markers such as."

sections.heading: 4 Data Set & Experimental Setup
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1 Dataset
sections.text: The data set used in the experiment is provided by the organizer of the PoS tagging tool competition at ICON2016 (Jamatia and Das, 2016), which consists of Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp statements on a fine and coarse-grained level. There are three different code-mixed language pairs English-Hindi, English-Bengali and English-Telugu, and data sets from the three major social media sites Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp are provided to build the system.

sections.heading: 4.2 Experiment
sections.text: CRF + + 1, an implementation of CRF, is used to perform the experiment. We have used the default CRF + + setting throughout the experiment. Since CRF + + uses a predefined feature template to find 1https: / / taku910.github.io / crfpp / the optimal feature template, a number of experiments on training data sets have been conducted in cross-validation mode. However, we only match the feature template to English-Hindi data sets and used the optimal template for all three language pairs.

sections.heading: 5 Results
sections.text: For this joint task, we submitted two separate, restricted runs, which differ in the nature of their training, while the functionality remains the same: 1. Run-1: The system was trained by extending the training data of each language pair from all three social media platforms, namely Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp. Therefore, the same model was used to obtain the POS tag from Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp test data; 2. Run-2: The system was individually trained with only corresponding language pair training data from different social media platforms, namely Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp. Therefore, the Facebook-trained model Twitter and WhatsApp training data was used to obtain the POS tag from Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp test data. The same strategy was used for both coarse and fine-grained training data from different social media platforms, namely Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp.

sections.heading: 6 Future work and Conclusion
sections.text: This article describes the approach to marking parts of the language on an ever finer and coarser level in Bengali-English, Hindi-English and Teluguan language pairing of code-mixed data. The system performed exceptionally well in all areas for finer and coarser tag sets, with the exception of the Telugu Twitter Constrained Run-2 on code-mixed tag sets. The team is currently working on the application of Deep Neural Networks in the task of PoS tagging. A lack of labelled data was the main cause of poor results in the application of Recurrent Neural Networks and Long-Short Term Memory (LSTM) models for the classification task. We are currently working on combining a CRF-based classification system and a Bi-Directional LSTM (BLSTM) model to improve results on code-mixed data sets.
